conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a dark area on the surface behind the object.
The size and position of a shadow depend on the distance and angle of the light source relative to the object.
In the first image, shadows A, B, C, and D are cast on the ground by the objects above them.
The light source is positioned such that the shadows are elongated and positioned at a certain distance from the objects.
When the light source moves backward, it increases the distance between the light source and the objects.
As the distance increases, the angle at which light hits the objects changes, affecting the shadows.
As the light source moves further away, shadows tend to become smaller because the light rays become more parallel.
In the second image, shadows A, B, C, and D appear smaller compared to the first image.
The position of the shadows will shift closer to the objects as the light source moves backward.
The angle of light incidence becomes less steep, causing the shadows to move closer to the base of the objects.
In the second image, shadows A, B, C, and D are smaller and closer to the objects compared to the first image.
When the light source moves backward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will become smaller in size and shift closer to the objects.
